author: Deleted User
content: <@!301186049323958275> (since you seem to have a good focus on how terms are used, help would be much appreciated).

author: sky.cactus
content: Depends on your target audience.  Random traders will recognize ETH faster, a more erudite audience will likely prefer Ether.

author: Deleted User
content: A non-technical generalist audience encountering Ethereum for the first time. It sounds like Ether would be the more formal or official version.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  Like saying "United States Dollar" instead of "USD".

author: sky.cactus
content: If your audience is unfamiliar with the shorthand, it is better to use the long form.

author: sky.cactus
content: Especially in this case, since the long form is only 2 characters longer.

author: potuz
content: Perhaps it's a matter of language or regions. But here, the very few people with whom I've spoken about this. Refer colloquially to Ether the token as "Ethereum" as a countable noun, eg "I just sold two Ethereums". I know it's wrong, just pointing out that "Ether" may throw some people off

author: Deleted User
content: I will definitely make clear the correct way to distinguish them. Often hear that myself.
